alert.note: Alert for Admiralty Island; Annette Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Wrangell; City and Borough of Yakutat; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Municipality of Skagway; Petersburg Borough; Prince of Wales Island (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 11 at 3:12PM AKDT by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...Stronger Winds and Potential for Heavy Rains Expected Thursday into Thursday Night... A strengthening low pressure system is expected to develop over the eastern Gulf of Alaska Thursday morning, and will move to the north passing west of the Alaska Panhandle Thursday into early Friday. As this low pressure area strengthens east of Prince of Wales and Baranof Islands Thursday afternoon and evening, winds will become strong at times with periods of heavy rainfall are expected. At this time, forecasters are seeing the potential of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall between Thursday morning and Friday morning over portions of the central Panhandle area to include Sitka, Hoonah, Angoon, Gustavus, Haines, Skagway and Juneau. These rainfall amounts are expected to result in a rise in river levels Thursday night into Friday, although rises above minor flood stage are not anticipated. The combination of heavy rains and stronger wind gusts Thursday afternoon into Thursday night could result in tree fall, resulting in the potential for some power outages. For areas to the north around Yakutat and to the south across the Klawock, Hydaburg, Ketchikan, Metlakatla, Petersburg and the Wrangell areas, while precipitation totals are expected to not be as heavy, the potential for strong wind gusts could still be there Thursday and Thursday night. Across some of the inner coastal waters of the Alaska Panhandle and offshore over the eastern Gulf of Alaska, strong winds to Gale force are expected Thursday afternoon through much of Thursday night. Those planning travel on the water should check the latest forecasts before leaving harbor and plan accordingly. Stay tuned for further updates and information from the National Weather Service on this developing storm system.
